thread.title: If Jake Arrieta pitches like Kyle Hendricks, can Hendricks pitch like Arrieta?
thread.title_full: If Jake Arrieta pitches like Kyle Hendricks, can Hendricks pitch like Arrieta? - Chicago Tribune

author: Steve Rosenbloom
title: If Jake Arrieta pitches like Kyle Hendricks, can Hendricks pitch like Arrieta?
text:
Jake Arrieta faced three batters in the first inning of Game 2 of the National League Championship Series and all Mets three batters scored.
Heck, they were only a triple short of hitting for the cycle.
For those of you scoring at home, Arrieta threw 30 pitches in the first inning with none reaching 95 miles an hour.
After that first inning, Arrieta had allowed seven earned runs in his last 6 2/3 playoff innings.
Someone’s a little confused about the concept of a stopper.
By the third inning, manager Joe Maddon was ordering Arrieta to walk Daniel Murphy intentionally while Travis Wood hurriedly warmed up.
By the fifth inning, Tommy La Stella was on deck to hit for Arrieta.
That’s not the Arrieta we watched all season, the one with three brilliant sliders and a fastball in the upper 90s, the one with the greatest second half in history, the one who asphyxiated the Pirates with a complete-game shutout in the wild-card game.
Jake Arrieta on Daniel Murphy, 1st inning struggles Jake Arrieta on Daniel Murphy, 1st inning struggles.
Jake Arrieta on Daniel Murphy, 1st inning struggles.
See more videos No, that’s the Arrieta we saw struggle against the Cardinals in the NL Division Series, the one who got worked by a lineup that refused to swing at balls and sat on strikes.
And that’s the Arrieta who has thrown more than 90 innings beyond his career best, the one who looks done for the year and is taking the Cubs postseason with him.
Here’s another way to look at it: The top four Cubs hitters were a combined 5-for-15, but knocked in only one run, while the top four hitters in the Mets lineup combined to go 5-for-14 with all four RBIs and all four runs.
Mets rookie pitcher Noah Syndergaard minimized the Cubs’ damage. Arrieta maximized the Mets’ chances of sweeping.
As the Cubs come home down 0-2, it comes down to this:
If Arrieta is going to pitch like your garden-variety Kyle Hendricks, then the Cubs have to hope Hendricks can pitch like the vintage Arrieta.
TBS analyst Ron Darling said he was shaking his head that the Cubs would walk Daniel Murphy intentionally to pitch to Yoenis Cespedes.
Kyle Hendricks on Game 3, facing Daniel Murphy Kyle Hendricks on Game 3, facing Daniel Murphy.
Kyle Hendricks on Game 3, facing Daniel Murphy.
See more videos Excuse me, Ron, but which of Murphy’s homers the last two days did you miss?
The problem wasn’t Maddon’s ordering Murphy walked intentionally. The problem was Arrieta’s not getting Cespedes.
In the postseason, Murphy has homered twice off Clayton Kershaw, and once off Zack Greinke and Arrieta. If it’s up to Murphy, nobody wins the Cy Young.
I lobbied for Maddon to move Kris Bryant down in the order to fifth because he was 0-for-14 on the road this postseason, so of course Bryant singles in the first inning and doubles in the sixth to account for the Cubs’ only run.
Odd but very baseball thing from Game 2: The bottom five spots in the Cubs and Mets batting orders went a combined 0-for-32.
It’s a stitch to hear Dusty Baker spend time on the TBS pregame show talking about great rookies when he’d never play any.
I drew criticism for not criticizing Starlin Castro for not hustling out of the box on his double in Game 1, and I was as wrong as Castro. But for those of you thinking triple, I think the cutoff throw would’ve gone to third instead of home and nailed him by a lot.
Kyle Schwarber and Mets outfielder Michael Conforto were teammates on the 2013 USA Baseball National Collegiate team that pulled off a historic five-game sweep of Cuba.
The Mets see your plexiglass-enclosed Schwarber home-run ball and raise you a Big Apple home-prop with a bandage where Travis d’Arnaud’s home run ricocheted in Game 1.
TBS should just admit that what it calls a pitch window is really just a heat map of Whack-A-Mole.
The Choice (and remember, death is not an option): Stupid NLCS talk of pizza vs. stupid NLCS talk of 1969?
But Jerry Seinfeld as the Mets' lounge act vs. Eddie Vedder as the Cubs’ house band -- now that’s an argument worth having.
 Major League Baseball Baseball Jake Arrieta Chicago Cubs Daniel Murphy New York Mets Kyle Hendricks
